Award.AwardTitle: Advancing QM/MM Methods to Model Reactions in Ionic Fluids
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods (CTMC) Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Orlando Acevedo and Jeffrey Overbey of Auburn University to develop and apply theoretical and computational approaches for ionic liquids. The Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering (CDS&E) program in the Division of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is contributing to the award. With over 100 million pounds of chemical waste treated yearly, a better understanding of how to optimize recyclable solvents for chemical reactions has the potential to impact society from the lab bench top to large-scale industrial manufacturing. Ionic liquids, recyclable solvents composed exclusively of ions, have the ability to accelerate and control a vast range of reactions. However, a new family of ionic fluids called deep eutectic solvents (DES) has recently emerged as an environmentally safer and relatively inexpensive alternative. As a medium for chemical reactions each solvent class has distinct advantages; however, the DES are only beginning to emerge as a potential substitute. The current study will help establish a firm understanding of the intermolecular interactions occurring throughout chemical reactions when solvated by ionic liquids and DES. The strategy is to employ high-end computational modeling to elucidate the effect of these ionic fluids upon the mechanism of product formation for important chemical reactions. Cross-training for students in both the chemical sciences and software development will be provided, preparing them for the STEM workforce. This proposal will also introduce computational chemistry to high school and undergraduate students through a hands-on Instant Supercomputer workshop featuring the construction of a temporary supercomputer.

Orland, Overbey and workers investigate chemical reactivity enhancements originating from ionic fluids and to develop new advances in QM/MM methodology. The objective is use QM/MM simulations to resolve controversies regarding the influence of ionic liquids and DES upon rate accelerations, mechanisms, and %ee enhancements when compared to conventional solvents. Development of force field parameters is proposed for multiple choline chloride based DES solvents and 1-alkyl-3-methylimidazolium based ionic liquids. In addition, the creation of a highly parallel, open source software package for performing QM/MM calculations will be made freely available to the scientific simulation community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advancing QM/MM Methods to Model Reactions in Ionic Fluids.

 

Due to the negative environmental impact of damaging organic solvents and the high-cost of chemical waste disposal, the search for alternative, renewable solvents is a top priority in the chemical industry. Conventional solvents account for the vast majority of waste in synthesis and processing, and are generally toxic, flammable, and/or corrosive. Part of a worldwide emphasis on improving sustainability, this push has led to increasing interest in a set of  environmentally-friendly solvents: ionic liquids and deep eutectic solvents. Attractive features of these solvents are their superior biodegradation, lower toxicity, and excellent thermal and chemical stabilities. As a medium for chemical reactions, these ionic fluids have significant popularity due to their ideal properties in catalysis and organic synthesis. Despite the excitement surrounding these solvents, a fundamental understanding of how they operate is still lacking. The research supported by this award was to develop and apply computer models to both elucidate how these solvents function and to design the next generation of cost-effective “green” solvents. Our results have provided computer models (“force fields”) capable of accurately reproducing and predicting experimental solvent properties. Significant technical advances have been developed in the form of algorithms, methodology, and new open-source software that allowed for faster and more accurate computer predictions of ionic liquid properties.

 

The educational objective of this proposal was to introduce computational chemistry to high school and undergraduate students through our hands-on “Instant Supercomputer!” workshop featuring the construction of a temporary supercomputer. Chemistry outreach events at science museums in Miami, FL and Ft. Lauderdale, FL were developed and performed for the local community.


Last Modified: 09/04/2018
Modified by: Orlando Acevedo

Images (1 of )
  • This graphic illustrates an equilibrated CCU deep eutectic solvent simulation box. OPLS-DES force field parameters have been constructed and validated for multiple choline chloride-based combinations.
    Orlando Acevedo
    Copyrighted
    Orlando Acevedo
    Deep eutectic solvent CCU
  • Illustration of a novel parameterization effort for imidazolium containing ionic liquids featuring a ?virtual atom? (in pink). The resultant OPLS-VSIL force field gave significant improvements to our previous OPLS-2009IL and is comparable in accuracy to high-level quantum mechanical calculations.
    Orlando Acevedo
    Copyrighted
    Orlando Acevedo
    OPLS-VSIL
  • This graphic illustrates the probability of locating an anion (in yellow) and cation (in blue) around the cation during the [BMIM][Cl] simulation giving a better sense of the solvent structure. Our OPLS-2009IL force field parameters have been constructed and validated for multiple ionic liquids.
    Orlando Acevedo
    Copyrighted
    Orlando Acevedo
    IL Solvent Structure
  • Interaction between the cation of the [BMIM][PF6] ionic liquid and the transition state of the MRH reaction of the Z-phenylhydrazone of 3-benzoyl-5-phenyl-1,2,4-oxadiazole. The reaction has been shown to derive a sizeable rate enhancement from using ionic liquids as a reaction medium.
    Orlando Acevedo
    Orlando Acevedo
    MRH Reaction in Ionic Liquids
  • Halloween themed National Chemistry Week events held at the science museums in Miami and Ft. Lauderdale sponsored and organized by the South Florida American Chemical Society local section.
    George Fischer

    Orlando Acevedo
    So-FLACS NCW events
